name: Gwen
comment info:
Native American Reservations are home to a majority of the nation’s bottom 1% of wealth and frequently have poor living conditions for the people living there. This is because a majority of the land is communally owned, meaning that no one can invest into improving the land or utilizing the often rich natural resources.  The issue of property rights and the risk of making a big investment without a legal footing is unappealing to investors, so those in the reservations are stuck in an endless cycle of poverty. Due to these conditions, tribes are confined to small areas of land to house their large population, so everyone is uncomfortably close together. This boasts some problems for social distancing in the pandemic, causing more people to catch the disease and therefore die. However, in the 65 and older age group, Hispanic people die the most due to COVID 19. I don't know why this sharp increase in Hispanic mortality occurred, but older people are more than 2x as likely on average to die from COVID-19 than their younger counterparts in the 40-64 group. 
I wonder if government funding to Native American reservations during the pandemic could have saved many lives, as well as other low-income communities. 
This is a wake-up call for many, as this graph highlights the disparity between communities, and how much a low-income status could affect something as seemingly unrelated as their chances of dying from COVID-19. 
The Disproportionate Effect of COVID on People of Colour

replies.name: K
replies.comment info: @Gwen I agree with you, the outcome could have been different for these low-income communities if the government had given resources to them. I think covid wouldn't  have given such a hardship for them if the resources were given.

name: Batya
comment info:
I notice that two graphs of different types describe different types of information about the same topic, Covid mortality by race and ethnicity. The first graph separates mortality rates per 100,000 people in each racial group by age. The second shows the life expectancy trends for different racial groups.

I wonder what actions can be taken to lessen the health disparities in some communities of color as shown in these graphs. Conversely, in groups with a higher life expectancy and lower mortality rates, what strategies and resources lead to those outcomes? I also wonder what part unconscious bias had to play in these health outcomes–were the higher mortality rates due to a lack of resources, money, expertise, etc., or because of bias (purposeful or accidental)

Health disparities in minority groups (such as racial groups as shown here or in other groups such as women) are a pervasive issue in communities across the United States. These disparities lead to worse health outcomes, including for other diseases and conditions besides Covid.

Title: "The Covid Survival Divide: does your race put you at risk?"

name: Rena
comment info:
I notice that all ethnic groups maintain the same ranking of life expectancy throughout age groups except for Hispanic people. People in the highest age group (65 years and older) exceeded the Covid death rate of Native people, but in the middle and lowest age groups (40-54, 18-39), both Native and Black people exceed the death rate of Hispanic people. It is interesting (and possibly concerning) that, according to the captions beneath both graphs from the CDC and the National Center for Health Statistics, the original data did not include Hispanic people as a separate category of data. 

I wonder what the causes were for the disparity between death rates between ethnic groups. Were these differences caused by some intrinsic, genetic vulnerability found only in some ethnic groups, an overall glut or lack of resources between ethnic groups, or a combination of the two? How would these graphs look if the samples chosen to represent each respective ethnic group were only immigrants? What if the samples were divided by social class? How much health care access, on average, did each of these ethnic groups have access to? 

This relates to my community because it brings attention to the fact that not everyone experiences equal risk of serious infection, and therefore death from Covid. 

Covid Doesn't Play By Equal Rules

name: Nina Okechukwu
comment info:
What do I notice?

I notice that Native people are the greatest racial group affected by Covid, with both older and younger ages of Native people dying from the virus. I also notice that the U.S life expectancy for Native people has drastically decreased, as the life expectancy for Native people was already low compared to other groups even before covid hit. 

What do I wonder?

I wonder why the life expectancy for Native people has been unusually low over the past few years compared to other races. I wonder why Asian people were the least affected by Covid, and I wonder if Asian people are taking more precautions to stay away from the virus, or if the death rate is low for other reasons. I also wonder whether or not different minority groups not having access to certain healthcare services affected the death rates. Additionally, I wonder if this is why white people have a lower death rate than black, Hispanic, and Native people. 

How does this affect my community?

Being a person of color, seeing the high death rate for minorities is very striking. Minorities are clearly dying at a very alarming rate, and it is concerning to see. Furthermore, it can be assumed that healthcare and overall access to healthcare play a major factor in the death rate and it is scary that it is more difficult for minorities to get proper treatment and healthcare that should be free and available to everyone. 
Title: Covid's Effect On People of Color

name: Emilia AOSE
comment info:
I notice in these graphs that over the past two years the life expectancy of each ethnicity in the U.S. has steadily declined.  The sharpest decline has occurred in the Indigenous population. The average life expectancy has lessened from roughly 78 to 76. The first graph shows the differences in how many people of each ethnicity in the US died from Covid. It is split up into age groups and as expected, the most deaths occurred in the category of 65+ years. The overall highest amount of deaths across all age groups was in natives. Following closely were Hispanic and Black deaths. The smallest amount of deaths occurred in Asian people. 
What I wonder is why some ethnicities have such drastic differences in their rates. I wonder if it has to do with geography and where they are concentrated in living, financial aspects, and health aspects.
This relates to me and my community because I know people who have had lasting effects of Covid and even died from it, but I was unaware of how it affected certain ethnicities.
A title for this graph would be "Will Covid Outlive Us All?"

comment info:
What do I Notice:
The first graph shows the amount of people who died in the US in in three different age groups: 18 to 39, 40 to 64, and ages 65 and older. Within each of these age groups the people surveyed are divided among five different ethnicities: native, hispanic, black, white, and asian. The second graph illustrates the life expectancy in the US  from 2019 to 2021 among the same five ethnicities. In 2020 the life expectancy of every group decreased. 

What do I wonder:
I wonder why the life expectancy of some nationalities were disproportionally affected by the Covid in the US. For instance, the life expectancy for the Native Americans is dropped about 6.6 years from 71.8 to 65.2, while the life expectancy for Asians decreased by about 1 year, from 85 to about 84.

In nearly every age group Native Americans have the greatest cumulative US Covid death rates. I also notice that people ages 65 and older are affected significantly more by Covid compared to younger demographics. In every age group Covid-19 had an impact in decreasing the life expectancy. 

How It Relates to My Community:
This relates to me and my community because I have lived in the United States throughout the Covid-19 pandemic. It is shocking to see the long-term impacts that the Coronavirus has had on the population.

name: Chantal Tejada
comment info:
1) I noticed that the older the people are the rates of Covid deaths increase. Also that the Black, Hispanic, and Native American community suffered more loss due to Covid. Life expectancy in the US decreased in every race/ethnicity group from 2019 to 2020. However, from 2020 to 2021 the race/ethnicity groups stayed relatively the same with the exception of Native whose life expectancy decreased significantly.   

2) I wonder what were the factors that targeted Native, Black, and hispanic. If perhaps it was due to the groups lifestyle or community. Also I wonder if what affected the most was the access these groups had to  resources against Covid, such as masks, gloves, and even information on how to be more protected. I wonder as well why the Native expectancy life continued to decrease between 2019 and 2020 even after all the other race/ethnicity groups either stayed the same or changed (decreased) but slightly.

3)  This relates to me and my community because as a Hispanic person I had many relatives pass away. And these graphs raise the question of what groups are prioritized in America and whether White and Asian people being the least affected by Covid in America is a coincidence or not. Which is a tough but important question because what Hispanic (immigrant) people, like my parents and I, seek for in America is freedom and opportunity and how could we find that without equality.    

4) "The Impact of Covid in different communities"

replies.comment info:

name: Nicholas
comment info: The first thing that I noticed when looking at these two graphs was the rough correspondence between the ethnic groups in the two metrics that were collected. I notice that on both the COVID deaths and life expectancy graphs, Native Americans are shown to have, by far, the most COVID deaths, and the lowest life expectancy out of the ethnic groups surveyed. I wonder why this is the case. It is likely due to the inequity in access to health care and services that Native American communities face compared to the rest of the United States. I think these graphs may help to understand the severity of their lack of medical resources and show the breadth of the consequences that only grew throughout the pandemic. In people aged 65+, the Hispanic population had the highest COVID death rate, whereas for every other age group it was dominated by Native Americans. Asians were shown to have the lowest death rates across all age groups and the highest life expectancy. I also noticed that of the lines depicting life expectancy, Black and Native life expectancies experienced the greatest change in 2020, despite the other ethnic groups’ curves flattening out. The reasons for this are abundant with nuances, especially before 2020. I wonder what actions were taken to address the Native COVID death rate. I wonder what the state, city, or county-specific data would look like and what kind of insight that could provide on how access to care/services in particular areas impacted COVID death rates.

name: I.B.
comment info:
I notice in the first graph that not only is the data separated by race (which has its own connotations I'll get to in a minute) but also by age. Interestingly enough, these 'cumulative death rates' for COVID-19 being separated both by race and by age seem to link the two in their relationship to COVID. The popular understanding of the virus is that it affects the old and not the young, a biological vulnerability of the elderly's frailty. Given that this is the case in our discussion, does it not also implicitly suggest that any correlation between race and COVID death rates is also biologically related, or otherwise unrelated to policy choices or political oppression? Something to consider.
On the subject of race, as usual, there is a false dichotomy (or whatever the term is for 5 groups). An unfortunate consequence of European colonialism is the flawed European understanding of race. No one person can be divided into one 'pure' racial category, despite what they might physically 'present' as. You would be pressed to find someone whose lineage is 'purely' of one racial category -- after all, the human race originated in Africa. Besides this, however, the differences in life expectation and death rates are easy to explain, and relatable to anyone living in poverty. If you are in prison and become infected, you die of COVID. If you are in prison, you are likely to be poor -- this lines up with being 'native', 'Hispanic', or 'black.' The same applies to life expectancy.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @I.B. --

You’ve tackled a lot here.  I strongly suggest that you return on Friday when we will reveal the New York Times article that included these graphs.  There, you can read about the factors that affect the health of Native Americans.  

I am not sure about whether Covid deaths are “biologically related.”  You may want to search online for support of this hypothesis.  Also, in these graphs, there is no link shown between race and age.  This analysis could be done, but it is not shown here.  You are correct about the effect of policy choices and its effect on the health of Native Americans.  More reasons are discussed in the article mentioned above.  Finally, statisticians are very particular about the use of the word correlation.  It can only be used when comparing quantitative variables.  For race and Covid death rates - a categorical and a quantitative variable, you can say they are associated.  

How about a catchy headline that captures the main idea of these graphs?
